title: Bayes' Theorem
text: The probability of event A given event B may be computed by means of the following formula: P(A$$\mid$$B)=P(A)P(B$$\mid$$A)/P(B)

title: Events
text: Let RR, BB, and RB denote, respectively, the events that the chosen card is the red-red, the black-black, or the red-black card. Let R be the event that the upturned side of the chosen card is red. Then the problem can be restated as calculating P(RB$$\mid$$R)=P(RB)P(R$$\mid$$RB)/P(R)

title: P(RB)
text: What is the probability that a randomly chosen card is RB? Enter your answer as a fraction

subHints.title: P(RB)
subHints.text: There are 3 cards in the hat, only 1 of which is RB. Thus the probability that a randomly chosen card is RB is $$\frac{1}{3}$$

title: P(R$$\mid$$RB)
text: What is the probability that the upturned side of the chosen card is red, given that the card is RB? Enter your answer as a fraction

subHints.title: P(R$$\mid$$RB)
subHints.text: Given that the chosen card is RB, one side is black and the other is red. Thus the probability that the upturned side is red is $$\frac{1}{2}$$

title: P(R)
text: What is the probability that the upturned side of the chosen card is red? Enter your answer as a fraction

subHints.title: P(R)
subHints.text: There are two cases in which the upturned side of the chosen card is red: the chosen card is RR and the upturned side is R, or the chosen card is RB and the upturned side is R (if the chosen card is BB, then the probability that upturned side is red is 0). Thus P(R)=P(R$$\mid$$RR)P(RR)+P(R$$\mid$$RB)P(RB)

subHints.title: P(RR)
subHints.text: There are 3 cards in the hat, only 1 of which is RR. Thus the probability that a randomly chosen card is RR is $$\frac{1}{3}$$

subHints.title: P(R$$\mid$$RR)
subHints.text: Given that the chosen card is RR, both sides are red. Thus the probability that the upturned side is red is 1

subHints.title: P(RB)
subHints.text: There are 3 cards in the hat, only 1 of which is RB. Thus the probability that a randomly chosen card is RB is $$\frac{1}{3}$$

subHints.title: P(R$$\mid$$RB)
subHints.text: Given that the chosen card is RB, one side is black and the other is red. Thus the probability that the upturned side is red is $$\frac{1}{2}$$

title: P(RB$$\mid$$R)
text: Use P(RB), P(R$$\mid$$RB), and P(R) to solve for P(RB$$\mid$$R) using Bayes Theorem
